Posts.Content: AUA guidelines call for patients post RPP with a Pt3a pathology to be counseled about adjuvant radiation. This is based solely on your pathology report and has nothing to do with your PSA level, although if your PSA is undetectable, the benefit oif adjuvant radiation is not clear.

Posts.Title: Surgery for High-Risk Patients -- some journal papers

Posts.Content: If the cancer was confined to the prostate, I can't imagine why he would have had radiation after the surgery. As has been noted, without knowing his post surgery psa numbers, very hard to say anything, but you're probably right. Something is pumping out psa. Sounds like your friend needs to educate himself. He can't let your doctor make the decisions for him, and a good doctor wouldn't do that.

Posts.Content: When were you tested for UTI's? Your doctor's "if it's not better by Monday" seems to be dictated by his schedule and not medical training. What condition that causes so much pain corrects itself? I'd find somebody to help me before Monday. Dehydrating yourself is just adding another problem to the existing one.

Posts.Title: It hurts bad when I Urinate

Posts.Content: My guess would be no, but it's not possible to know just because you have a little blood in your semen, which can be caused by a number of different things. When was your last psa and what was it? What was your Gleason score? Obviously, you should see a doctor, because you shouldn't have blood in your semen, especially if it is persistent. The blood is coming from somewhere. As far as PC, it is usually very slow to develop and you would have rising PSA long before it caused symptoms like blood in your urine.

Posts.Title: PSA increase follow up:

Posts.Content: It's possible to identify likely cancer with an MRI, but it is not possible to diagnose without a biopsy. My interpretation is that the radiologist recommends a biopsy because of the "multi-nodular" median lobe. Your father needs a biopsy. I don't know what state you are in or your father's immigration status, so I can't direct you to any resources to help pay for his medical bills.

Posts.Title: Suspect prostate cancer. Help needed.

Posts.Content: mom2two: given the time it took for your dad's psa to rise and its low level, he should be fine. His "stats" are uncannily similar to my own, but I'm recently out of surgery. The advice of your RO is exactly the same as the advice he gave us. I think I would pull the trigger on radiation if my psa had a steady rise over .04. Let us know what he does and how it works out.

Posts.Title: PSA increase follow up:

Posts.Content: The surgery removes the smooth muscle tissue that acts as the urinary sphincter for men. We have a second set of muscles that can act as a sphincter, but for many men, they are not sufficiently developed to function satisfactorily. The sphincter that was removed was controlled by the autonomic nervous system, meaning that we don't have to think about it, and thinking about it doesn't make any difference. Since this sphincter works automatically, we don't have much reason to work the other set of muscles. The pelvic floor muscles that act as a sphincter after surgery are normal muscles under our conscious control. You need to train them to work properly, and you can do so with the Kegel exercises. It may take a little while to get them to work properly for this purpose. Don't give up, it will come.

Posts.Title: PSA increase follow up:

Posts.Content: Hi McCloud, As a prominent RO told me, if it takes that long (in your case seven years) for the PSA to rise, how aggressive can that cancer possibly be? It is true that most of the time when the PSA rises to .03 it is likely to reach BCR. But that doesn't mean that .03 or .06 is BCR. Think of it as a risk factor. It is not inevitable, just likely. I would find a good RO and see what he or she tells you. Nothing about your numbers suggests that you're in any trouble. Let us know how it works out.
